subject: Ethics
title: Jury Nullification Debate
description: A short lesson to help you apply Jury Nullification Debate.

hook.text: A jury finds a man guilty of a crime they think shouldn't be a law. They vote 'not guilty' anyway.

buildup.text: Jury nullification means jurors acquit despite clear evidence of guilt because they oppose the law itself.

discovery.text: It has a noble history: northern juries refused to convict people who helped escaped slaves before the Civil War.

twist.text: But it has a dark side too. All-white juries in the South nullified to acquit murderers of Black citizens.

climax.text: Nullification is both democracy's safety valve and its backdoor for injustice. Same power, opposite outcomes.

punchline.text: The same power that freed slaves also freed their killers.

quiz.question: Why is jury nullification considered ethically complex?
options: It has never been used successfully in any real court case
It can be used both to protect justice and to perpetuate injustice, depending on the jury
It is explicitly prohibited by the U.S. Constitution
